<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[750, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A thin solid disc of radius \(r\) and thickness \(z\) is attached to a thin axle. String is wrapped around the axle, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 113, 780, 387]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 403, 532, 421]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 435, 473, 452]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(m\) is attached to the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 465, 917, 513]]<|/det|>
The block is released from rest and falls downwards. The block has speed \(v\) when it has fallen through a distance \(h\) from the point of release. The value of \(v\) is determined using one light gate connected to a timer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 527, 568, 543]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) is related to \(m\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 553, 575, 586]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{h}{\nu^2} = \frac{\pi r^2 z}{2PQm} + \frac{1}{P}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 593, 366, 609]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 624, 695, 640]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(v\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 654, 623, 670]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 685, 702, 701]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 715, 382, 731]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 746, 393, 762]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 776, 410, 791]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 806, 348, 821]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 836, 350, 851]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 865, 447, 880]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 102, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates a circuit containing capacitors. The circuit is connected with a capacitor of capacitance \(A\) , as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[365, 116, 626, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 440, 532, 457]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 471, 802, 488]]<|/det|>
Two capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\) , are connected in parallel between P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 502, 635, 518]]<|/det|>
Initially, switch X and switch Z are closed and switch Y is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 533, 918, 580]]<|/det|>
Switches X and Z are opened. Switch Y is then closed. The maximum potential difference between P and Q is measured using the voltmeter. This procedure is repeated and the mean maximum potential difference \(V\) between P and Q is determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 594, 917, 626]]<|/det|>
The experiment is then repeated by changing the number \(n\) of capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), connected in parallel between P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 640, 571, 656]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(n\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 670, 566, 688]]<|/det|>
\[E A = V(nC + A)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 702, 581, 718]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 733, 148, 753]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 732, 657, 760]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(n\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 768, 611, 785]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 876, 917, 893]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 908, 917, 925]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ....................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 925, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 107]]<|/det|> Values of \(n\) and the two measured values of the maximum potential difference \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 845, 460]]<|/det|>
\(n\)\(V_{1}/V\)\(V_{2}/V\)\(V/V\)\(\frac {1}{V}/V^{-1}\)
24.304.20
33.653.75
43.303.20
52.852.95
62.652.55
72.302.40
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 485, 918, 536]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(V/V\) and \(\frac{1}{V}/V^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in \(V\) and \(\frac{1}{V}\). [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 547, 144, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 180, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 541, 682, 571]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{V}/V^{-1}\) against \(n\). Include error bars for \(\frac{1}{V}\). [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 578, 178, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 577, 918, 610]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 624, 180, 642]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 624, 918, 656]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 825, 918, 842]]<|/det|>
gradient = ........................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 211, 917, 228]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ........................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 243, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(E\) and \(C\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 289, 393, 306]]<|/det|>
Data: \(A = (2.2 \pm 0.2) \text{mF}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 473, 917, 490]]<|/det|>
\[E = \text{...........................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 505, 917, 522]]<|/det|>
\[C = \text{...........................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 520, 918, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 552, 180, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 552, 662, 570]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(C\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 675, 917, 693]]<|/det|>
\[\text{percentage uncertainty} = \text{.....................................................................} \% \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 707, 146, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 707, 918, 740]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated with 10 capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), connected in parallel between P and Q. Determine the maximum potential difference \(V\) between P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 850, 917, 867]]<|/det|>
<form>V = ........................................................................... $V$
